abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Lignite Power
            Technical Assistance Project for Kosovo is to provide
            environmental and social safeguard support to facilitate the
            successful development and investments within the new mining
            field including the development of a new lignite mine and
            power station, in a manner consistent with international
            best practices in regard to the management of the social,
            economic, and environmental impacts of such developments.
            Some of the negative impacts of the project are: i) burning
            of open mines and explosion/burning of waste dump sites; ii)
            risk of exposure to hazardous substances into the open
            pits/open dumps; iii) direct contact with contaminated
            soils; iv) pollution at work places (dust, noise emissions,
            etc); v) air emissions and air quality monitoring; vi)
            particulate emissions from thermal power plants (TPP)
            transport system and from ash dumps; vii) contaminated Storm
            water due to leaching of contaminated soils; viii) noise
            pollution; and ix) potential for air pollutants deposition
            on the soil from power plants. Mitigation measures of the
            project are: 1) immediate securing (including fencing) of
            the open mine and waste dump sites to prevent unauthorized
            access; 2) implement access restriction devices and maintain
            them in operation through a periodic verification service;
            3)  impacted soil mapping should be prepared and appropriate
            fencing/labeling should be introduced; 4) monitoring
            campaign on noise to measure 8 hours dose and air quality
            especially at the mines; 5) installation of settling ponds
            to reduce the load of suspended solids and coal dust in mine
            water; and 6) a noise survey should be undertaken both at
            the work place or at the main receptors to be identified. A
            proper comparison with applicable standards should be
            performed in order to ascertain potential non compliance and
            necessary mitigation measures.
